page.title: 06FARMING IN CRUWYS MORCHARD 2
page.content: The main crop grown is grass, covering 90% of the area. Half is for grazing, half is conserved for winter feed, 95% as silage, 5% as hay. Up to 3 cuts of silage are made annually. 300 tonnes of straw are imported each year from other areas for fodder and bedding. Sheep remain out all year apart from a short period before and after lambing. Cows and bullocks are housed throughout the wet, cold winters. Large, airy buildings of concrete block or wood with roofs of asbestos sheeting have replaced the small dark cob hovels. They have wide central passageways and doorways enabling tractors to enter with equipment; dump fodder and bedding and remove dung. Machinery is stored under high-roofed open-sided structures. A few large old stone barns remain and are used for storage of hay, seeds and equipment.
